events.title: Birth
events.summary: François Couperin was born in Paris into a prominent musical family, receiving early music lessons from his father, Charles, who was an organist. His lineage included notable musicians, including his uncle Louis Couperin. His father's passing in 1679 led to François being positioned as the organist at the Church of Saint-Gervais, a role which he likely began to assume at an earlier age than expected.
events.fun_version: François Couperin was born in Paris to a prominent musical family, which could probably serenade the Eiffel Tower into submission! His father, Charles, was an organist, and it's said that François learned to play music before he learned to tie his shoelaces. Not to forget, his uncle Louis was also a notable musician! After his father's passing in 1679, young François stepped up as the organist at the Church of Saint-Gervais!

events.title: Marriage
events.summary: At the age of 21, Couperin married Marie-Anne Ansault, who came from a prosperous family. This union marked a significant personal milestone in his life amidst a budding musical career.
events.fun_version: At the ripe old age of 21, Couperin decided it was a great time to tie the knot with Marie-Anne Ansault. This union marked a significant personal milestone in his life! You know, nothing says 'I'm ready for a serious career in music' like getting hitched to someone from a prosperous family! Who needs stability when you've got a budding career and a partner ready to support it, right?

events.title: Publication of Pièces d'orgue
events.summary: In 1690, the year following his marriage, Couperin saw the publication of his collection of organ masses titled Pièces d'orgue. This collection garnered praise from notable figures in the musical community, suggesting a positive reception among his peers.
events.fun_version: In 1690, the year after Couperin's marriage, he published his collection of organ masses called 'Pièces d'orgue.' This collection was so well-received and garnered praise from notable figures in the musical community, suggesting a positive reception among his peers, that even they were likely applauding louder than a toddler at a birthday party!

events.title: Appointment at Louis XIV's court
events.summary: Within three years after his marriage, Couperin succeeded Jacques-Denis Thomelin at the court of Louis XIV, connecting him with the finest composers and the aristocracy of the time. This appointment greatly influenced his career and musical output, including his chamber music.
events.fun_version: Within three years after his marriage, Couperin succeeded Jacques-Denis Thomelin at the court of Louis XIV, which meant he was rubbing elbows with the crème de la crème of composers and aristocrats. This appointment didn’t just get him some fancy friends; it jazzed up his music career and sparked his chamber music.

events.title: Publication of harpsichord works
events.summary: In 1713, Couperin applied for a privilege to publish works of his composition, which he utilized to release the first volume of his harpsichord pieces, Pieces de clavecin, marking an expansion of his published repertoire and influence.
events.fun_version: Back in 1713, Couperin decided he couldn't just sit quietly while his compositions gathered dust. So, he applied for a fancy privilege to publish his works, claiming he had revolutionary harpsichord pieces. This clever move allowed him to release 'Pieces de clavecin', marking an expansion of his repertoire and turning him into the celebrity of the harpsichord world!

events.title: Final publications
events.summary: François Couperin published his final music works, Pièces de violes in 1728 and the fourth volume of his harpsichord pieces in 1730, signaling the culmination of his prolific compositional career prior to his death.
events.fun_version: François Couperin finally decided it was time to put down the quill – after all, his last music works, Pièces de violes in 1728 and the fourth volume of his harpsichord pieces in 1730, signifying the culmination of his prolific compositional career like a well-aged cheese!

events.title: Death
events.summary: François Couperin passed away in 1733, having made significant contributions to the French Baroque music scene and leaving behind a legacy through his children, particularly as his daughter continued his musical tradition at court.
events.fun_version: François Couperin, who decided that 1733 was a good time to check out of this wild party called life, left behind a musical legacy that would make even his children proud. His daughter heroically carried on his musical tradition at court, ensuring that the Couperin name resonated through the halls of French Baroque music!

works.title: 7 Versets du motet composé de l'ordre du roy, 1704
7 Versets du motet composé de l'ordre du roy, 1705
Rondeau in B-flat major, BWV Anh.183
